revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name = Alexander Kapitokhin |native_name = Александр Григорьевич Капитохин |image = Alexander Kapitokhin.jpg |birth_date = 6 June 1892 |death_date = 13 August 1958 |birth_place = Kamenka-Loginovka village, [[Yelets]] ''[[uyezd]]'', [[Orel Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] |death_place = [[Moscow]] |allegiance = {{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{USSR}} |branch = [[Russian Imperial Army]]
[[Soviet Army]] |serviceyears = 1914–1917; 1918–1950 |rank = [[Lieutenant general]] |commands = [[95th Rifle Division]]
[[10th Airborne Corps]]
[[8th Guards Airborne Division]]
[[Soviet airborne]]
[[38th Guards Airborne Corps]]
[[38th Guards Rifle Corps]] |battles = [[World War I]]
[[Russian Civil War]]
[[Estonian War of Independence]]
[[Polish-Soviet War]]
[[World War II]] *[[Siege of Sevastopol (1941–42)|Siege of Sevastopol]] *[[Battle of the Dnieper|Dnieper Airborne Operation]] |awards = {{Order of Lenin}}
[[Order of the Red Banner]] (3)
[[Order of Suvorov]] 2nd class
[[Order of Bogdan Khmelnitsky (Soviet Union)|Order of Bogdan Khmelnitsky]] 2nd class
[[Order of Suvorov]] 3rd class
[[Order of the Red Star]]
[[Order of the Badge of Honor]] }}'''Alexander Grigoryevich Kapitokhin''' ([[Russian language|Russian:]] Александр Григорьевич Капитохин; 6 June 1892 – 13 August 1958){{Cite web|title = Biography of Lieutenant-General Aleksandr Grigorevich Kapitokhin – (Александр Григорьевич Капитохин) (1892–1958), Soviet Union|url = http://www.generals.dk/general/Kapitokhin/Aleksandr_Grigorevich/Soviet_Union.html|website = www.generals.dk|accessdate = 2015-10-01}} was a [[Red Army]] [[Lieutenant general]]. Kapitokhin commanded a sector in the final [[Siege of Sevastopol (1941–42)|defence]] of [[Sevastopol]] and was later the commander of the [[Soviet Airborne Troops]] (VDV).{{Cite book|title = Sevastopol 1942: Von Manstein's Triumph|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=InhYvzlG4QAC|publisher = Osprey Publishing|date = 2008-01-01|isbn = 9781846032219|first = Robert|last = Forczyk}} He was awarded the [[Order of Lenin]] and three [[Order of the Red Banner|Orders of the Red Banner]].{{Cite book|title = Великая Отечественная: Комкоры. Военный биографический словарь|last = Zhukovsky|first = Mikhail|publisher = Kuchkovo|year = 2006|isbn = 9785901679111|location = |pages = }} == Early life == Kapitokhin was born in Kamenka-Loginovka village, [[Eletsky County]], [[Oryol Governorate]].{{Cite web|title = Александр Григорьевич Капитохин|url = http://www.tstu.ru/win/tambov/imena/mih/kapitoh.htm|website = www.tstu.ru|accessdate = 2015-09-26}} He graduated from the fourth grade of rural school. He studied at the teacher's school for three years and graduated in 1909 with the rank of primary school teacher. In 1911 he graduated from another teachers' college and became a teacher of Russian language and literature in Borisoglebovskoe village, where he worked until conscription in 1914. == World War I == Kapitokhin was drafted into the [[Imperial Russian Army]] in October 1914. He became a [[Private (rank)|private]] in the 147th Infantry Reserve Regiment, based in [[Kuznetsk]]. From May to October 1915, he was educated at the [[Chuguyev]] [[Junker (Russia)|Junker School]] and graduated as a lieutenant. From June 1916, he was a company commander in [[Irkutsk]], first with the 10th Siberian Infantry Reserve Regiment and then with the 11th Siberian Infantry Reserve Regiment. In September 1916, Kapitokhin was sent to the [[Western Front (Russian Empire)|Western Front,]] where he fought with the 31st Siberian Infantry Regiment. In December 1917, he was [[Demobilization|demobilized]]. == Russian Civil War == Kapitokhin was an instructor in the [[Yelets|Eletsky]] union of Consumer Societies. In December 1918 he joined the [[Red Army]]{{Cite book|title = Великая Отечественная война. Большая биографическая энциклопедия [Great Patriotic War Biographical Encyclopedia]|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=yYzSAAAAQBAJ|publisher = Litres|date = 2015-04-22|isbn = 545727697X|language = ru|first = Konstantin|last = Zaleski|page = 1952}} and was appointed the commander of a battalion of the 99th Rifle Regiment of the [[11th Rifle Division]]. In March 1919 Kapitokhin was transferred to the same post in the 98th Rifle Regiment. As part of the 11th Rifle Division, Kapitokhin fought in the [[Estonian War of Independence]] and against forces commanded by [[Stanisław Bułak-Bałachowicz]]. In July he commanded the assault group of the [[Western Army (Russia)|Western Army]]. In October he was assistant commander and then commander of the 23rd Brigade of the [[8th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|8th Rifle Division]]. Kapitokhin fought in the [[Polish–Soviet War]] and was captured in January 1920 in [[Bobruisk]]. He spent four months in [[POW|prison]], but escaped during the Soviet May offensive. Kapitokhin was awarded his first [[Order of the Red Banner]] during the same year.{{Cite book|title = Сборник лиц, награжденных орденом Красного Знамени и почетным революционным оружием [Persons awarded the Order of the Red Banner]|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=c_33BQAAQBAJ|publisher = Directmedia|date = 2013-03-14|isbn = 9785446060313|language = ru}} In October 1920 and February 1921 he commanded the [[1st Rifle Brigade|1st Separate Rifle Brigade]] on the {{illm|Caucasian Front (Russian Civil War)|lt=Caucasian Front|ru|Кавказский фронт (Гражданская война)}}. == Interwar period == Kapitokhin served with the [[6th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|6th Rifle Division]] in the [[Belorussian SSR]], where he was the assistant commander of the 16th and 18th Rifle Regiments. In November 1923, he was sent to study at the Red Army infantry commander school. After graduation in September 1924, Kapitokhin demobilized.{{Cite web|title = Раздел 1. Тамбов — судьбы начало|url = http://gaspito.ru/index.php/component/content/article/493|website = gaspito.ru|accessdate = 2015-10-01|last = Administrator}} He went to the [[Frunze Military Academy]], from which he graduated in October 1931.{{Cite book|title = Воздушно-десантные войска [Airborne Troops]|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=KAwhAQAAIAAJ|publisher = Голос-Пресс|date = 2003-01-01|language = ru|first = А. Г. [A.G.]|last = Шпак [Shpak]}} He became a [[reservist]] and was the chief of the Office of Defence Mobilization of the Central Union of Consumer Societies. Kapitokhin was then the chief of the weather station on [[Uyedineniya Island]].{{Cite book|title = RAEM – мои позывные [RAEM – My Callsign]|last = Krenkel|first = Ernst|publisher = |year = |isbn = |location = Moscow|pages = |url = http://vivovoco.astronet.ru/VV/PAPERS/BIO/KRENKEL/RAEM/RAEM.HTM}} On 24 September 1939, he became the deputy head of the [[Chief Directorate of the Northern Sea Route]]. For his work in the Arctic, Kapitokhin was awarded the [[Order of the Badge of Honour]] and given the title "Honorary Polar Explorer". In 1940 he was promoted to [[Colonel]]. == World War II == After [[Operation Barbarossa]] Kapitokhin was placed at the disposal of the Military Council of the [[Odessa Defence Region]]. In August 1941 he was appointed commander of the 161st Rifle Regiment{{Cite book|title = Glory eternal; defence of Odessa, 1941|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=o1AJAQAAIAAJ|publisher = Progress Publishers|date = 1972-01-01|language = en|first = Nikolaĭ Ivanovich|last = Krylov}}{{Cite book|title = The Commander|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=-LMfAAAAMAAJ&q=kapitokhin&dq=kapitokhin&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCoQ6AEwA2oVChMIi7ndivCgyAIVh4uSCh35kAMi|publisher = Brassey's Defence Publishers|date = 1987-01-01|isbn = 9780080362618|language = en|first = Vladimir|last = Karpov}} of the [[95th Rifle Division]] in the [[Separate Coastal Army]].{{Cite book|title = Where the Iron Crosses Grow: The Crimea 1941–44|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=LyNEBAAAQBAJ|publisher = Osprey Publishing|date = 2014-09-20|isbn = 9781782006251|language = en|first = Robert|last = Forczyk}} In March 1942, he became the commander of the division.{{Cite book|title = Битва за Севастополь. Последний штурм [The Battle of Sebastopol: The final assault]|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=o4BoCgAAQBAJ|publisher = Litres|date = 2015-08-22|isbn = 9785457868205|language = ru|first = Oleg|last = Nuzhdin|first2 = Stanislav|last2 = Ruzaev}} Kapitokhin fought in the [[Siege of Sevastopol (1941–42)|Siege of Sevastopol]] and commanded the 4th sector of the city's defences during the final assault.{{Cite book|title = Лед и пламень [Ice and Fire]|last = Papanin|first = Ivan D.|publisher = Politizdat|year = 1977|isbn = |location = |pages = |url = http://militera.lib.ru/memo/russian/papanin_id/18.html}} On 4 July he was evacuated by submarine to [[Novorossiysk]]. For actions in the defence of Sevastopol, Kapitokhin was awarded the [[Order of the Red Banner]]. On 29 August Kapitokhin became the commander of the [[10th Airborne Corps]] in the [[Moscow Military District]]. On 10 November 1942 he was promoted to [[Major general]]. On 8 December 1942 Kapitokhin became commander of the [[8th Guards Airborne Division]].{{Cite book|title = The Organization and Order of Battle of Militaries in World War II: Volume V – Book B Union of Soviet Socialist Republics|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=KVmIOFNvQw4C|publisher = Trafford Publishing|date = 2009-11-01|isbn = 9781426922510|language = en|first = Charles D.|last = Pettibone|page = 6}} On 23 March, he was awarded the [[Order of Suvorov]], 3d class.{{Cite web|title = Подвиг народа [Alexander Kapitokhin Citation for award of Order of Suvorov 3rd class]|url = http://podvignaroda.ru/?#id=16942161&tab=navDetailManAward|website = podvignaroda.ru|accessdate = 2015-10-09}} In July 1943 the division fought in the [[Battle of Kursk]]. In August he became the commander of the [[Soviet airborne|Soviet airborne troops]]. In September 1943 Kapitokhin organized the [[Battle of the Dnieper|Dnieper Airborne Operation]].{{Cite book|title = Stalin's War with Germany: The road to Berlin|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6UaU6ZLqK4UC|publisher = Yale University Press|date = 1999-01-01|isbn = 0300078137|language = en|first = John|last = Erickson|page = 127}} The Dnieper Airborne Operation was a failure,{{Cite book|title = The History of Soviet Airborne Forces|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=0erZZt-EGDQC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher = Taylor & Francis|date = 1994-01-01|isbn = 9780714641201|first = David M.|last = Glantz}} and Kapitokhin was demoted afterwards for alleged incompetence. In August 1944 Kapitokhin was appointed commander of the [[38th Guards Airborne Corps]]{{Cite web|title = КАПИТОХИН Александр Георгиевич — Десантура.ру – о десанте без границ|url = http://desantura.ru/persona/42/|website = desantura.ru|accessdate = 2015-10-12|last = Kruglov|first = V.A.}} as part of a separate airborne army. On 5 November, he was promoted to [[Lieutenant general]]. In November 1944 he was also awarded the Order of the Red Banner. In January 1945 the corps became part of the [[9th Guards Army]]. Until February 1945 it was held in [[Stavka|Stavka Strategic Reserve]]. In March the corps became part of the [[3rd Ukrainian Front]] and fought in the [[Vienna Offensive]]. Kapitokhin was an adviser with the Bulgarian [[First Army (Bulgaria)|First Army]] and the Yugoslav [[3rd Army (Yugoslav National Liberation Army)|3rd Army]]. At the end of the war, Kapitokhin was in Dalmatia. == Postwar == Kapitokhin was appointed chief of the [[Tambov Suvorov Military School]] in November 1945. In July 1950, he was discharged due to illness. Kapitokhin died in Moscow on 13 August 1958 and is buried in the [[Vagankovo Cemetery]]. == References == {{Research help|Mil}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kapitokhin, Alexander}} [[Category:Soviet lieutenant generals]] [[Category:Commanders of the Soviet Airborne Forces]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Lenin]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Red Banner]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Suvorov, 2nd class]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Suvorov, 3rd class]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Bogdan Khmelnitsky (Soviet Union), 2nd class]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Red Star]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Badge of Honour]] [[Category:1892 births]] [[Category:1958 deaths]] [[Category:Soviet military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:People from Oryol Governorate]] [[Category:Soviet prisoners of war]]
